questions.correct_answer: A. Mass is mobile perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mass is mobile perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line The patient has a significant swelling moving perpendicular to the attachment of mesentery characterized by a triad known as the Tillaux Triad . TILLAUX TRIAD Soft fluctuant swelling in the periumbilical region. Zone of hyper-resonance around the swelling. I am swelling, moving perpendicular to the attachment of mesentery. CT Scan: CT Scan of Mesenteric Cyst. Unilocular appearance without a solid component strongly suggests a benign cyst.

Highyeild:

Chylolymphatic cysts arise from lymphatic tissue that is congenitally misplaced and has no communication with the lymphatic system. They mainly occur in the mesentery of the ileum , have a thin wall filled with clear lymph or chyle , and can attain a large size. They are primarily unilocular and solitary and have an independent blood supply from the adjacent intestine, making enucleation possible without gut resection. Enterogenous cysts are derived from a diverticulum of the mesenteric border of the intestine or duplication of the intestine . They have a thicker wall than chylolymphatic cysts and are lined by mucous membranes, sometimes ciliated. Their mucinous content can be colorless or yellowish-brown due to past hemorrhage. The muscle in their wall and adjacent bowel share a standard blood supply, and their removal always entails resection of the corresponding portion of the intestine.

Table:

#MANTRA Mesenteric cysts can be of different types, including chylolymphatic, straightforward (mesothelial), heterogeneous, urogenital remnant, and dermoid (teratomatous cyst). Clinical features of mesenteric cysts include a painless abdominal swelling, recurrent attacks of abdominal pain with or without vomiting, acute abdominal pain, and Tillaux triad (fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus that moves freely in a plane perpendicular to the attachment of the mesentery, and a zone of resonance around the cyst). CT scan is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of mesenteric cysts, while ultrasound is also helpful. Treatment for chylolymphatic cysts is enucleation , while heterogeneous cysts require resection and anastomosis . Aspiration alone has a high rate of cyst recurrence.

options.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.correct_answer: B. Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS Given case history and findings point to the diagnosis of tension pneumothorax. No apparent cause or known underlying lung pathology characterizes spontaneous pneumothorax or primary spontaneous pneumothorax . There may be contributing factors, such as cigarette smoke, family history, and rupture of the bulla (tiny air-filled sacs in the lung tissue), but these will not cause pneumothorax. Secondary or non-spontaneous or complicated pneumothorax occurs due to an underlying lung pathology such as COPD , Asthma , Tuberculosis , Cystic Fibrosis , or Whooping Cough. A pneumothorax can further be classified as a tension or non-tension pneumothorax.

Highyeild:

A tension pneumothorax is caused by excessive pressure buildup around the lung due to a breach in the lung surface which will admit air into the pleural cavity during inspiration but will not allow any air to escape during expiration. The breach acts as a one-way valve. This leads to lung collapse . The air is removed through the surgical incision by inserting an underwater drain in the pleural cavity. This excessive pressure can also prevent the heart from pumping effectively, which may lead to shock. A non-tension pneumothorax is not considered as severe as there is no ongoing accumulation of air, and therefore there is no increased pressure on the organs and the chest. Treatment options include: Conservative management with observation until the body naturally resorbs the air Simple aspiration Chest tube placement - Simple chest tube placement alone has a high recurrence rate (about 65%) in patients with LAM. Heimlich valve (HV) insertion - a lightweight one-way valve designed for the ambulatory treatment of pneumothorax (with an intercostal catheter) Pleurodesis through a chest tube - a procedure that obliterates the pleural space to prevent future pneumothoraces. Mechanical (using physical abrasion) Chemical (using talc, doxycycline, bleomycin , or other agents) . While chemical pleurodesis through a chest tube can be successful, this may result in incomplete pleurodesis due to the uneven distribution of the chemical. Surgery - Surgical treatment using video-assisted thoracoscopy (VATS) , is the preferred approach. A wide bore needle in the 5th ICS followed by ICD/ Thoracostomy is the most appropriate approach for this patient in the emergency setting.

questions.text: According to Strasberg’s classification of bile duct injury. Injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type C Strasberg classification of bile duct injuries and strictures: Class A: injury to small ducts in continuity with the biliary system, with a leak in the duct of Luschka or the cystic duct. Class B: injury to a sectoral duct, resulting in obstruction of part of the biliary system. Class C: injury to a sectoral duct with bile leak; bile leakage occurs from a duct not continuous with the biliary system. Class D: lateral injury to the extrahepatic biliary ducts. Class E1: stricture >2 cm from the bifurcation of the right and left bile ducts. Class E2: stricture <2 cm from the bifurcation of the right and left bile ducts. Class E3: stricture at the bifurcation of the right and left bile ducts. Class E4: stricture involving the right and left bile ducts; the left and right ducts are not continuous. Class E5: complete occlusion of all bile ducts, including sectoral ducts.

Table:

#MANTRA Bile duct injuries The rate of bile duct injury during open cholecystectomy is low (0.1-0.2%), while it is higher during laparoscopic cholecystectomy (0.3-0.85%). Bile duct injury can be caused by acute or chronic inflammation, obesity, anatomic variation, bleeding, acute cholecystitis, pancreatitis, cholangitis, and obstructive jaundice . Inadequate surgical technique and failure to identify structures before ligating or dividing them are common causes of significant biliary injury. Intraoperative cholangiography may help limit the extent of bile duct injury but does not prevent it. Symptoms of bile duct injury may include jaundice with or without abdominal pain. Major ductal injuries are often recognized intraoperatively due to bile leakage, abnormal cholangiogram, or late anatomy recognition. Patients may present with cholangitis or cirrhosis months or years after prior surgery due to a biliary tract injury. Diagnosis of bile duct injury involves imaging studies like USG or CT . The patient should be stabilized with immediate parenteral antibiotics, image-guided percutaneous drainage of fluid collections , and Cholangiography done to identify the level and nature of the Postoperative biliary strictures are best diagnosed with PTC , while ERCP is useful for patients with bile duct continuity who require urgent cholangiography and biliary decompression. CT arteriography is useful in preoperatively evaluating patients with benign biliary strictures to detect unrecognized injury to the hepatic artery or a portal vein branch. In patients presenting with late strictures with evidence of liver dysfunction, a CT arteriogram should be performed to evaluate for evidence of portal hypertension.

More than half of patients with biliary injury will present within the first postoperative month. The remainder will present months or years later, with recurrent cholangitis or cirrhosis from a remote bile duct injury. In the early postoperative period, patients present either with a progressive elevation of liver function tests due to an occluded or a Stenosed bile duct or with a bile leak from an injured duct. Bile leak, most commonly from the cystic duct stump, a transected aberrant right hepatic duct, or a lateral injury to the main bile duct, usually presents with pain, fever, and a mild elevation of liver function tests. questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly seen tumor in Retroperitoneal space?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Liposarcoma The lipoma is the most common benign soft tissue tumor. Liposarcomas are one of the most common soft tissue sarcomas and frequently occur in the extremities and the retroperitoneum of adults.

Highyeild:

Retroperitoneal lipoma Retroperitoneal lipomas may present as a swelling or abdominal pain, often affecting women, and can grow to a large size. Diagnosis is commonly made through ultrasound and CT scanning . A retroperitoneal lipoma can undergo myxomatous degeneration , which is a complication not seen in lipomas elsewhere in the body. There is a risk of malignancy ( liposarcoma ) in retroperitoneal lipomas, which can rapidly increase in size.

questions.text: A young girl presents with complaints of continuous dribbling of urine. However, she also voids normally, and her parents tell you that she has never been dehydrated since her birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ectopic ureter Opens in the vestibule of the vagina that is distal to external urethral sphincter due to which there is continuous dribbling of urine.

Highyeild:

An ectopic ureter drains to regions other than the bladder. Ectopic ureters are almost always associated with ureteric duplication and are bilateral in 10%. The female-to-male ratio is 7:1. In females, the ectopic ureter opens either into the urethra below the sphincter or into the vagina Such a child would complain of incontinence of urine despite normal voiding. In contrast, the male child is always continent as the ureter opens above the external urethral sphincter. Computed tomo-urography (CTU) or magnetic resonance urography (MRU) is diagnostic.

questions.text: A 40-year old female presents with the complaints of swelling of the left breast over the past 15 days. On examination, it was mobile over the chest wall with the local rise of temperature. What is your likely diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inflammatory CA The given history and clinical findings are suggestive of inflammatory carcinoma of the breast . Patients with inflammatory carcinoma usually have a history revealing the rapid onset of disease (15 days in the above case) with progression over weeks to 3 months. The hallmark of inflammatory breast cancer is diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatic channels within the breast and overlying skin, often without an underlying tumor mass. Inflammatory breast cancer manifests clinically as erythema (as shown in the mage), edema and warmth of the breast due to lymphatic obstruction. There may be no abnormality on mammography beyond skin thickening and a palpable mass is not required for the diagnosis. Inflammatory breast cancer i s the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer . The pathologic hallmark of inflammatory cancer is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics . Axillary nodal metastases are common, and a significant risk exists for distant metastases. Giant fibroadenomas are usually seen in the early reproductive years. These are benign solid encapsulated tumors . It is a slow-growing tumor and presents as a painless lump in the breast. Phyllodes tumor , aka osteosarcoma phyllodes, is generally present as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin though the overlying skin becomes thin and tense due to swelling. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition. Galactocele usually presents as a solitary subareolar cyst.

questions.text: A female with metastatic liver adenocarcinoma with Ck7-, CK20+, and CDX-1, HC markers. Which of the following is the most likely primary for this metastasis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Colon Ca carcinoma CK profile Possible primary tumor CK7+ CK20+ Bladder, pancreas, ovary (mucinous) CK7+ CK20- Breast, ovary, endometrium, thyroid (papillary ca), lung (nonsmall cell) CK7- CK20+ Colorectal CK7- CK20- Hepatocellular, prostate, renal and squamous and neuroendocrine lung tumors

Highyeild:

Colorectal cancer Colorectal cancer is the second most common cause of cancer death in the UK, with approximately 42,000 new cases diagnosed each year. Colon cancer represents about two-thirds of cases, while rectal cancer accounts for the remaining one-third. Men are more affected than women, with 56% of cases occurring in men. The adenoma-carcinoma sequence is the prevailing theory on how most colorectal cancers develop. The APC gen e is mutated early in carcinogenesis and is present in two-thirds of colonic adenomas. K-ras mutations are more commonly found in larger lesions, indicating a later occurrence in mutagenesis. The p53 gene is frequently mutated in carcinomas but not in adenomas, making it a marker of invasion.

Extraedge:

A recent international consortium identified four consensus molecular subtypes (CMSs) of colorectal cancer based on gene expression analysis in over 4000 patients. CMS1 is characterized by MSI , a feature of Lynch syndrome , which may occur sporadically, mainly in right-sided tumors. CMS2 is characterized by WNT and MYC signaling activation . CMS3 is characterized by metabolic dysregulation. CMS4 is characterized by transforming growth factor beta activation.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl with slow-growing non-Tender swelling in the lateral part on the side of the neck, as shown in the image. Examination shows the presence of freckles and light skin patches over the face and trunk. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neural tumor Café - au-lait spots is seen in neurofibroma. A collection of pigment-producing melanocytes causes them in the epidermis of the skin. These spots are typically permanent and may grow or increase in number over time. Café au lait spots are often harmless but may be associated with syndromes such as neurofibromatosis type 1 and McCune–Albright syndrome. Cystic hygroma - Present at birth, present at the anterior triangle. Also known as cystic lymphangioma and macrocystic lymphatic malformation, the growth is often a congenital lymphatic lesion of many small cavities (multiloculated) that can arise anywhere, but is classically found in the left posterior triangle of the neck and armpits. The malformation contains large cyst -like cavities containing lymph , a watery fluid that circulates throughout the lymphatic system . Microscopically, cystic hygroma consists of multiple locule filled with lymph. Deep locules are quite big, but they decrease in size towards the surface. Lipoma- Positive slip sign. Chemodectoma- compressible swelling.

The close relationship of the external laryngeal nerve to the superior thyroid artery puts the nerve at potential risk when the artery is clamped during thyroid surgeries.
